video.title: HashiCorp Terraform Associate Certification Course - Pass the Exam!
video.description:
Prepare for the HashiCorp Terraform Associate Certification and pass! The Terraform Associate certification is for Cloud Engineers specializing in operations, IT, or development who know the basic concepts and skills associated with open source HashiCorp Terraform.

Get your Free Practice and Downloadable Cheatsheets: https://www.exampro.co/terraform

📢 View this course updates: https://www.exampro.co/terraform Last Updated: October 4 2021

✏️ Developed by Andrew Brown of ExamPro
🔗 https://twitter.com/andrewbrown

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:17:01) IaC Concepts
⌨️ (00:37:32) HashiCorp
⌨️ (00:41:39) Terraform Basics
⌨️ (02:00:07) Terraform Provisioners
⌨️ (03:03:46) Terraform Providers
⌨️ (03:43:39) Terraform Language
⌨️ (03:48:27) Variables and Data
⌨️ (04:34:30) Resource Meta Arguments
⌨️ (05:15:07) Terraform Expressions
⌨️ (06:01:28) Terraform State
⌨️ (06:12:34) Init and Get
⌨️ (06:15:01) Fmt, Validate, Console
⌨️ (06:18:09) Plan and Apply
⌨️ (06:24:19) Infrastructure Drift
⌨️ (06:39:34) Terraform Troubleshooting
⌨️ (06:49:03) Terraform Modules
⌨️ (07:28:20) Team Workflows
⌨️ (08:05:31) Terraform Backends
⌨️ (09:41:14) Resources and Complex Types
⌨️ (09:52:02) Built-In Functions
⌨️ (10:22:22) Terraform Cloud
⌨️ (10:46:02) Terraform Enterprise
⌨️ (10:55:39) Workspaces
⌨️ (11:58:34) Packer and Terraform
⌨️ (12:25:56) Consul and Terraform
⌨️ (12:27:05) Vault and Terraform
⌨️ (12:59:58) Alantis, CDK for Terraform, GruntWork, Terragrunt, TerraTest
⌨️ (13:08:29) Booking Your Exam

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Wong Voon jinq
👾 hexploitation
👾 Katia Moran
👾 BlckPhantom
👾 Nick Raker
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster
👾 AppWrite

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Frank T
topLevelComment.text:
graph output has problems when directly run in Powershell. Workaround is to either use WLS or run it via cmd . It can be called indirect from Powershell with following 
"cmd /c "terraform graph | dot -Tsvg > output.svg"'

topLevelComment.author: Joey Jojo
topLevelComment.text:
i recently got Terraform Associate Certified and I just wanna say that this certification does NOT represent my ability using Terraform
i found the exam to be nonsense really, it didn't actually test my ability and instead how well i read the white papers on what version of Terraform supports what and who is able to write providers etc ... i passed with an 85% but i could've failed with a 45% 'cause honestly a lot of it was guessing so just wanted to say that certifications these days are way overrated. In the end, they really just prove how much a person was able to cram before attempting the exam but as a DevOps Engineer I can tell you that I have worked with individuals who have 8 certs and then can't solve a simple port and/or DNS issue so don't get too caught up trying to get certified and instead focus on learning how to use all types of tools and make sure you know the basic concepts 'cause what's the point of being AWS/Terraform/Kubernetes/Docker certified if you can't figure out a simple firewall/ip/auth issue? just keep that in mind

topLevelComment.author: Bambang Gunawan
topLevelComment.text: I just passed the exam with 92%, resources that use: 1x Terraform Up and Running, 1x this video (at 1x speed and follow along with all the lab), 2nd iteration of Terraform Up and Running (also follow along all the lab), all the official study guide from Hashicorp, one more ExamPro video with 2x speed just to recap, practice exam with ExamPro, Udemy practice exam. Quite a lot but my goal is not just to pass the exam, but to get myself really understand IaC. From my opinion, the exam is not difficult, questions mostly are straight forward, not much scenario based question, and I didn't get any built-in function question. My approach on the exam, I finished all the 57 questions quickly in 20minutes+ and slowly review from beginning. Good luck for all who are preparing for the exam! btw for those who have concern with the AWS running cost for all the follow along, for me it's just cost me under $1, just make sure to destroy your deployment after each test and use cloud-nuke to make sure no resources running that you might not aware of.

topLevelComment.author: Glenn Sisson
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for the free material, I'm about 5 hours in now.  I must say though that I am getting more and more frustrated with the number of typos you make. Probably the root issue is your keyboard and mouse and the speed with which you use them... they just don't seem to work well for you... lots of bizarre cut and paste errors. Frustrated as well by your tendency to jump to the documentation when just re-reading what you had typed/pasted would have sufficed to find many error. Often I saw the typo as you made it, although other times you copy/pasted and then scrolled up/down so fast I couldn't even read what you had written/pasted. Maybe use a smaller font next time and remove the blank lines so more text is visible both to yourself and your viewers. Maybe use side-by-side windows as well. But anyway, thanks for sharing your sessions... I do appreciate it!

topLevelComment.author: David Ribeiro
topLevelComment.text:
I've got my certification today (07/March/2022) here are my opinions.  I hope it helps others:

1) I used this video and practice exams from Udemy(hashicorp certified: Terraform associate practice exam 2022 (which sucked by the way)) as resources. Nothing more. I didn't skip parts of the video and I've paid attention. I studied for 7 days (01/Mar to 07/Mar).

2) The exam kicked my ass and I had several questions about topics that I had not seen either in this video or the practice exams.

3) I had several questions that required knowledge about the details.. ("what would happen if X was done after Y in the situation W" kind of questions).  Although I also had a LOT of brain dead question ("what is the first command you run to initialize xxxx?")

4) I distinctly remember being quietly pissed off during my exam by the sheer number of questions I've had not seen in either materials I've used to study. It was the first time I had that experience.

5) I had about 2 "fill the blank by typing" questions, about 15 "true or false" and the rest were regular questions. I felt really unprepared for the "true or false" ones since they often asked about some obscure detail I had not been told about.

6)I've passed by the skin of my teeth with 72% - the lowest score I've ever had in a certification.  I had enough time to go through the questions 2 times and really think about my answers. The ones I got wrong I absolutely had no knowledge about.

7) The 2 "fill the blank by typing" questions were "what flag do you use when using the command *Terraform XXXX*  to have Y behavior?". Super simple stuff. It's just a gimmick. (I'll not get into details since I've agreed to not divulge the test)

8) It is amazing how many questions about "what is/are the benefit(s) of IaC?" They can come up with. There were at least 7 in my exam in different flavors. They are really keen on selling their solution and the answer is not super clear sometimes. 

9) Hashicorp does not play around and I respect them a lot for that. All questions were pretty direct and there were no tricky questions. Either you know or you don't.

My conclusion:
This is a great(free!) course and it got me through my certification. I will not complain about it. I thank the creator and will send him a $$ contribution asap. But DO NOT believe the comments saying this is an easy certification that you can pass half asleep.  In my opinion, It was as hard as my aws solutions architect associate (and I got a 92% on that one!)
Please read the documentation available on hashicorp's website or use other courses to supplement this one.  

Reading the comments here and on other sites I was sure this exam was going to be easy as hell.. it was NOT. Don't make the same mistake I did. ;)

topLevelComment.author: Ash Siddiqui
topLevelComment.text: Excellent Tutorial.. I am still at the start but something I noticed which I thought to highlight... you said 'Ansible' is not Idempotent but coming from an Ansible background I think it is...   Ansible modules are idempotent. For example, if one of the tasks is to create a directory on the server, then the directory will be created if and only if it does not already exist..

topLevelComment.author: theTertiaryAdjunct
topLevelComment.text: @ 4:22:25 he calls submodules with .//submodules - using 2 slashes // - why?  i have never seen a module called with 2 slashes.  linux treats it as one slash anyway, so WHY force 2 slashes

replies.author: theTertiaryAdjunct
replies.text: so after digging and asking - the double slashes are not required - - only when deliminiting a git subdirectory in a path.  So ./submodule would have been better

topLevelComment.author: Nicolas Humbert
topLevelComment.text:
1:55:00 ish  
Recent problem I encountered: Invalid credentials for AWS authentication when you use Terraform Cloud.

1. You need to remove the profile "default" from your code which gives (assuming you've already fixed vpc azs line with correct infos): provider "aws" {}
2.  Add AWS_PROFILE "default" in your env variables in Cloud.
3. terraform plan/apply

Used 4.0.0 AWS provider version.

Took 3 hours to find out, if someone has the answer i'd be happy to read it.

replies.author: M.O.
replies.text:
I am going crazy, nothing works for me at all, whatever I do, I receive the same Error: error configuring Terraform AWS Provider: failed to get shared config profile, default
Anyone else tried different approaches ?
I set up env vars in the cloud, I tried mentioned solutions, same result
Edit: my problem was I had some variables set in file as well as in the cloud, after removing duplicates, all worked

replies.author: Birendra Shrestha
replies.text:
This worked for me. Latest Terraform version and AWS provider

provider "aws" {
  #profile = "default"
  shared_credentials_files = ["~/.aws/credentials"]
  region = "us-east-1"
}

provider "aws" {
  #profile = "default"
  shared_credentials_files = ["~/.aws/credentials"]
  region     = "eu-west-1"
  alias      = "eu"
}
AWS_DEFAULT_REGION
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
Above env variables created in Terraform cloud.

replies.author: Boris Tsigelman
replies.text: @ooorkanooo AFAIR, the lock on the file is set by the bucket and not by TF. So, when you create the bucket in s3, you need to enable the locking feature of the bucket.

replies.author: ooorkanooo
replies.text: Hey, idk how it work with TF cloud but in a collabaratively environment you would save the tfstate to a bucket (s3 in aws for example) tf manages the "backend" and places a lock when someone runs a plan...

topLevelComment.author: el3m3ntxero

Good stuff.

topLevelComment.author: Suresh Katari
topLevelComment.text:
TLDR: 
Step 1: install aws cli
Step 2: configure/edit configuration file in ~/.aws/credentials.

PS: During the initial configuration of credentials file,  you mentioned installing aws cli after editing the credentials file. But you need to have aws cli installed prior to configuring the credentials file as it will be generated only after installing aws cli.

topLevelComment.author: Dustin
topLevelComment.text: The statement on "multi-cloud configuration" needs clarification because it seems to perpetuate this non-truth that the same configuration file that worked specifically Azure could be pointed to AWS, instead.  That is not true.  The statement should be along the lines that your configuration file can deploy resources via multiple providers and go on to say that it would require each provider to be defined and separate resource configuration written.
